_[Figure from xkcd](https://xkcd.com/882/)_  
_The never ending saga of p-values_

[The ASA Statement on p-Values: Context, Process, and Purpose](http://amstat.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00031305.2016.1154108)  
with comments at   
[Supplemental Material to the ASA Statement on P-Values and Statistical Significance](http://amstat.tandfonline.com/doi/suppl/10.1080/00031305.2016.1154108?scroll=top)  
was published in 2016 as an editorial in _The American Statistician_, with 21 comments from renowned statisticians, and a list of relevant references. 

**Meeting 1 - Spetember 7th**

  a. The ASA Statement on p-Values: Context, Process, and Purpose (Ronald L. Wasserstein & Nicole A. Lazar)  

  b. Statistical Tests, P-values, Confidence Intervals, and Power: A Guide to Misinterpretations (Sander GREENLAND, Stephen J. SENN, Kenneth J. ROTHMAN, John B. CARLIN, Charles POOLE, Steven N. GOODMAN, and Douglas G. ALTMAN)  
_This is a general introduction to the topic highlighting common misinterpretations, therefore it is a good place to start (if not as a refresher) before tackling the statement itself_

**Meeting 2 -  September 21st**

  1. Altman,Naomi: Ideas frommultiple testing of high dimensional data provide insights about reproducibility and false discovery rates of hypothesis supported by p-values
  2. Benjamin, Daniel J, and Berger, James O: A simple alternative to p-values
  3. Benjamini, Yoav: It's not the p-values' fault
  4. Berry, Donald A: P-values are not what they're cracked up to be
  5. Carlin, John B: Comment: Is reform possible without a paradigm shift?
  6. Cobb, George: ASA statement on p-values: Two consequences we can hope for
  7. Gelman, Andrew: The problems with p-values are not just with p-values


**Meeting 3 - October 19th**

  8. Goodman, Steven N: The next questions:Who,what,when, where, and why?
  9. Greenland, Sander: The ASA guidelines and null bias in current teaching and practice
  10. Ioannidis, John P.A.: Fit-for-purpose inferential methods: abandoning/changing P-values versus abandoning/changing research
  11. Johnson, Valen E.: Comments on the ASA Statement on Statistical Significance and P-values" and marginally significant p-values
  12. Lavine, Michael, and Horowitz, Joseph: Comment
  13. Lew, Michael J: Three inferential questions, two types of P-value

**Meeting 4 - November 2nd**

  14. Little, Roderick J: Discussion
  15. Mayo, Deborah G: Don't throw out the error control baby with the bad statistics bathwater
  16. Millar,Michele: ASA statement on p-values: some implications for education
  17. Rothman, Kenneth J: Disengaging from statistical significance
  18. Senn, Stephen: Are P-Values the Problem?
  19. Stangl, Dalene: Comment
  20. Stark, P.B.: The value of p-values
  21. Ziliak, Stephen T: The significance of theASA statement on statistical significance and p-values
